sub_title: Associate Professor of English Literature at University of Leiden
summary:
My research focuses primarily on the interaction between literature and religious culture in early modern England (approximately 1500–1700), with a special interest in the Reformation and the (religious) history of the human body. Recently, I’ve ventured beyond the early modern period for a book on literary representations of interpersonal reconciliation from Shakespeare until the present day (see publications for more details).

I’m also interested in (and have published on) the cultural-historical of suffering more broadly, in the history of consolation literature and in the question of how cultural-historical research can help us understand and address modern-day questions surrounding the experience of illness.

I mainly teach courses on English literature from 1500 to 1800. In addition to first- and second-year courses on Renaissance and eighteenth-century literature, I offer a third-year module on Shakespeare and Politics and an MA module on John Milton’s Paradise Lost.
